But wanders here, carrying her own sad Coffin,
Seeking some Desart place to lodge her greifes in.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sweet sorrow welcome, welcome noble griefe;
How got you this faire liberty to see me?
For sorrows in your shape are strangers to me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I come to counsell ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye are still more welcome;
For good friends in afflictions give good councels.
Pray then proceed.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Pray eate first, ye shew faint;
Here's Wine to refresh ye too.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I thank ye deere.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Drinke again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Here's to our loves.
How, turn and weepe!
Pray pledge it: this happinesse we have yet left,
Our hearts are free. Not pledge it? why,
And though beneath the axe this health were holy,
Why doe ye weep thus?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I come to woe ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To woe me Sweet? I am woe'd and wonne already,
You know I am yours. This pretty way becomes ye.
But you would deceive my sorrows; that's your intent.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I would I could, I should not weep, but smile.
Do ye like your Meat and Wine?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Like it?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Do you like your liberty?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: All these I well may like.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Then pray like her that sent'em.
Doe ye like wealth, and most unequal'd beauty?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Peace, indeed you'l make me angry.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Would I were dead that aske it,
Then ye might freely like, and I forgive ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What like, and who? adde not more misery
To a man that's fruitfull in afflictions.
Who is't you would have me like?
Who sent these comforts?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I must tell.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Be bold.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: But be you temperate.
If you be bold I die. The young fair Virgin;
(Sorrow hath made me old.) O hearken,
And wisely harke, the Governesse daughter:
That Star that strikes this Island full of wonder,
That blooming sweetnesse.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: She sent it: and with it,
It must be out, she dotes on ye,
And must enjoy ye: else no joy must find ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And have you the patience to deliver this?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: A sister may say much, and modestly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A Sister?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Yes, that name undid ye;
Undid us both: had ye nam'd wife, she had fear'd ye;
And fear'd the sin she followed; She had shun'd, yea
Her Virgin modesty had not touch'd at ye.
But thinking you were free, hath kindled a fire,
I feare will hardly be extinguisht.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Indeed I played the foole.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O my best sir, take heed,
Take heed of lies. Truth though it trouble some minds,
Some wicked minds, that are both darke and dangerous:
Yet it preserves it selfe, comes off pure, innocent,
And like the Sunne, though never so ecclips'd,
Must breake in glory. O sir, lie no more.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye have read me a faire Lecture,
And put a spell upon my tongue for fayning.
But how will you counsell now?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Ye must study to forget me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Be patient.
Be wise and patient, it concerns ye highly.
Can ye lay by our loves? But why should I doubt it?
Ye are a man, and men may shift affections,
Tis held no sin. To come to the poynt,
Ye must lose me; many and mighty reasons.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Heare me Aminta,
Have you a man that loves you to, that feeds ye,
That sends ye liberty? has this great Governesse
A noble sonne too, young, and apt to catch ye?
Am I because I am in bonds, and miserable,
My health decay'd, my youth, and strength halfe blasted,
My fortune like my wayning selfe, for this despis'd?
Am I for this forsaken? a new love chosen,
And my affections, like my fortunes wanderers?
Take heed of lying, you that chid me for it;
And shew'd how deep a sin it was, and dangerous.
Take heed, your selfe, you swore you lov'd me deerly;
No few, nor little oathes you swore Aminta,
Those seal'd with no small faith, I then assur'd my selfe.
O seek no new waies to cozen truth.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I do not.
By Love it selfe I love thee,
And ever must, nor can all deaths dissolve it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why do you urge me thus then?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: For your safety,
To preserve your life.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: My life I do confesse is hers,
She gives it,
And let her take it back, I yeild it.
My love's intirely thine, none shall touch at it;
None, my Aminta, none.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Ye have made me happy,
And now I know ye are mine. Fortune, I scorn thee.
Go to your rest, and Ile sit by ye;
Whilst I have time Ile be your mate, and comfort ye,
For onely I am trusted: you shall want nothing,
Not a liberty that I can steal ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: May we not celebrate our loves Aminta?
And where our wishes cannot meet

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: You are wanton,
But with cold kisses Ile allay that feavor;
Look for no more, and that in private too.
Believe me I shall blush else.
But let's consider, we are both lost else.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let's in, and prevent fate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You do well to ayre us Ladies, we shal be musty else.
What are your wise wils now?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are very cranck still.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: As cranck as a holy Fryer, fed with hayl-stones.
But do ye bring us out to baite, like Buls?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Or are you weary of the charge ye are at?
Turn us abroad again, let's jog Ladies;
We are grosse, and course, unfit for your sweet pleasures.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Knock off our shoos, and turn's to grasse.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are determined
Still to be stubborn then: it well becomes ye.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: An humour Lady that contents a prisoner.
A sullen fit sometimes serves for a second course.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ye may as well be kind,
And gain our favours; gain meat, and drink,
And lodging to rest your bones.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: My bones have bore me thus long,
And had their share of pains, and recreations;
If they fayl now, they are no fayr companions.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Are ye thus harsh to all our sex?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We cannot be merry without a Fidler.
Pray strike up your Tabors, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: The fools despise us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We know ye are very hungry now.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Yes, tis very wholsome Ladies;
For we that have grosse bodies, must be carefull.
Have ye no piercing ayre to stir our stomacks?
We are beholding to ye for our Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why slaves, tis in our power to hang ye.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Very likely.
Tis in our powers then to be hang'd, and scorn ye.
Hanging's as sweet to us, as dreaming to you.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Come, be more courteous.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do, and then ye shal be pleas'd, and have all necessaries.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Give me some Rats-bane then.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: And why Rats-bane, Mounsier?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: We live like vermin here, & eate up your Cheese,
Your mouldy Cheese, that none but Rats would bite at;
Therefore tis just that Rats-bane should reward us.
We are unprofitable, and our Ploughs are broken;
There is no hope of Harvest this yeere, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ye shall have all content.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I, and we'l serve your uses.
I had rather serve hogs, there's more delight in't;
Your greedy appetites are never satisfied;
Just like hungry Camels, sleeping or waking
You chew the cud still.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: By this hand we'l starve ye.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Tis a Noble courtesie.
I had as liefe ye should famish me, as founder me,
To be jaded to death is onely fit for a hackney.
Here be certain tarts of tar about me,
And parcels of potargo in my Jerkin,
As long as these last.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Which will not last ever.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Then we'l eate one another like good fellows,
A shoulder of his for a hanch of mine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Twill be, as we'l dresse it Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Why sure ye are not men.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Ye had best come search us,
A Seaman is seldome without a salt Eele.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am bad enough,
And in my nature a notorious wencher;
And yet ye make me blush at your immodesty.
Tell me good Master, didst ever see such things?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I could like 'em though they were lewdly given,
If they could say no; but fie on 'em,
They gape like Oysters.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Well, ye may hang, or starve us;
But your commanding impudence shall never feare us.
Had ye by blushing signs, soft cunnings, crept into us,
And shew'd us your necessities: we had met your purposes,
Supply'd your wants. We are no Saints Ladies;
I love a good wench, as I love my life,
And with my life I will maintain my love:
But such a sordid impudence Ile spit at.
Let's to our dens again. Come noble Master.
You know our minds Ladies:
This is the faith in which we'l die. Exit Tib. and Mast.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I doe admire 'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They are noble fellows,
And they shall not want, for this.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: But see, Clarinda comes. Enter Clarinda.
Farewell, Ile to my charge.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Bring out those prisoners now,
And let me seee 'em, and heare their businesse.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I will, Maddam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I hope she hath prevail'd upon her brother.
She has a sweet tongue, and can describe the happinesse
My love is ready to fling on him.
And sure he must be glad, and certain wonder
And blesse the houre that brought him to this Island.
I long to heare the full joy that he labours with.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Blesse thy Divine beauty.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Mirror of sweetnesse.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ever springing brightnesse.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, stand up Gentlemen, and leave your flatteries.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Shee cals us Gentlemen, sure we shall have some meat now.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I am a mortall creature,
Worship Heaven, and give these attributes
To their Divinities. Methinks ye look but thin.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: O we are starv'd, immortall beauty.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We are all poor starv'd knaves.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Neither liberty nor meat Lady.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: We were handsome men, and Gentlemen, & sweet men,
And were once gracious in the eyes of beauties,
But now we look like rogues;
Like poore starv'd rogues.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What would ye do if ye were to die now?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas we were prepar'd. If you will hang us,
Let's have a good meale or two to die with,
To put's in heart.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Or if you'l drown us,
Let's be drunk first, that we may die merrily,
And blesse the founders.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye shal not die so hastily.
What dare ye do to deserve my favour?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Put us to any service.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Any bondage,
Let's but live.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Wee'l get a world of children,
For we know, ye are hainously provided that way;
And ye shal beat us when we offend ye;
Beat us abundantly, and take our meat from us.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: These are weak abject things, that shew ye poor ones.
What's the great service ye so oft have threatned,
If ye might see me, and win my favour?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That businesse of discovery.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: O, Ile tell ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: and so will I.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And I,
Pray let me speak first.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Good, no confusion.
We are before a Lady that knows manners;
And by the next, meat I shall eate, tis certain.
This little Gentlewoman that was taken with us

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your Captains sister, she you mean.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I, I, she's the businesse that we would open to ye.
You are cousned in her.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How, what is't you would open?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is no sister.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Good sirs, how quick you are.
She is no sister, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is his.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Peace I say.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What is she?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Faith, sweet Lady,
She is, as a man would say, his.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: His Mistris.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Or, as some new translators read, his.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: And why he should delude you thus,
Unlesse he meant some villany? these ten weeks
He has had her at Sea for his own proper appetite.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: His Cabin-mate, Ile assure ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No sister, say ye?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No more then I am brother to your beauty.
I know not why he should juggle thus.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do not lie to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: If ye find me lie, Lady, hang me empty.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How am I fool'd!
Away with 'em, Juletta, and feed 'em
But hark ye, with such food as they have given me.
New misery!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nor meat, nor thanks for all this. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Make 'em more wretched.
O I could burst! curse and kill now,
Kill any thing I meet. Juletta, follow me,
And call the rest along.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: We follow Maddam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I must be gone now, else she may suspect me;
How shall I answer her?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Tell her directly.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: That were too sudden, too improvident;
Fires of this nature must be put out cunningly,
They'l waste all come neere 'em else.
Farewell once more.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Farewell.
And keep my love entire.
Nay kisse me once again, me thinks we should not part.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O be wise, sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, one kisse more.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Indeed you'r wanton; Enter Clarinda, Juletta, Crolale, Hippolita.
We may be taken too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Out thou base woman.
By Heaven Ile shoot 'em both.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Nay stay, brave Lady, hold;
A sudden death cuts of a Nobler vengeance.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Am I made Bawd to your lascivious meetings?
Are ye grown so wise in sin?
Shut up that villaine: and sirra,
Now expect my utmost anger.
Let him there starve.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I, mock at your mischiefes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tie that false witch unto that Tree,
There let the savage beasts
Gnaw of her sweetnesse, and Snakes
Embrace her beauties; tie her, and watch
That none relieve her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We could wish ye better fortune Lady,
But dare not help ye.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Be your own friends, I thank ye.
Now onely my last audit, and my greatest, Enter Raymond.
O Heaven, be kind unto me,
And if it be thy wil, preserve.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Who is this?
Sure tis a woman; I have trod this place,
And found much footing: now I know tis peopl'd.
Ha, let me see! tis her face.
O Heaven! turn this way mayd.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O Raymond, O brother.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Her tongue to: tis my sister; what rude hand!
Nay kisse me first, O joy!

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Fly, fly deere brother,
You are lost else.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A man, a man, a new man.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: What are these? Enter Juletta, Crocale, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: An Enemy, an Enemy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Dispatch him,
Take him off, shoot him straight.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: I dare not use my sword, Ladies,
Against such comely foes.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O brother brother!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Away with 'em, and in darke prisons bind 'em.
One word replyd, ye die both.
Now brave mother follow thy Noble Anger,
And Ile help thee. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Rossella, Clarinda, Crocale, Juletta, Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I am deaf to all your intreaties: she that moves me
For pity or compassion to these Pirates,
Digs up her fathers, or her brothers Tombe,
And spurns about their ashes.
Couldst thou remember what a father thou hast once,
Twould steele thy heart against foolish pity.
By his memory, and the remembrance of his deere embraces,
I am taught, that in a Noble cause revenge is Noble;
And they shal fall the sacrifices to appease
His wandering Ghost, and my incensed fury.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The new come prisoner to?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Him to. Yet that we may learn
Whether they are the same, or neere ally'd
To those that forc'd me to this cruell course,
Better their poore allowance, and permit'em
To meet together and confer,
Within the distance of your eare; perhaps
They may discover something that may kill
Despaire in me, and be a means to save 'em
From certain ruine.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: That shal be my charge.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yet to prevent
All hope of rescue: for this new come Captain
Hath both a ship and men not far off from us,
Though ignorant to find the onely Port,
That can yeeld entrance to our happy Island,
Guard the place strongly, and ere the next Sunne
Ends his diurnall progresse, I wil be
Happy in my revenge, or set 'em free. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Crocale, Juletta, Hippolita. A Table furnisht.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: So serve it plentifully,
And lose not time to enquire the cause;
There is a main design that hangs upon this bounty.
See the Table furnisht with Wine too,
That discovers secrets which tortures cannot open:
Open the doores too of the severall prisons,
And give all free entrance into this room.
Undiscover'd I can here marke all. Enter Tib. Mast.
Here's Captain carelesse, and the tough Ship-master,
The slaves are nos'd like Vultures
How wilde they look.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ha, the mystery of this,
Some good Hobgoblin rise and reveale.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I am amazed at it: nor can I sound the intent.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Is not this Bread,
Substantiall bread, not painted?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: But take heed,
You may be poysoned.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am sure I am famisht;
And as the wise man says,
Gripes the guts as much as any Minerall.
This may be Treacle sent to preserve me
After a long fast: or be it Vipers spittle,
Ile run the hazzard.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We are past all feare, Ile take part with ye.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Do: and now yfaith, how d'e feel your selfe?
I finde great ease in't. What's here?
Wine, and it be thy will;
Strong lusty Wine. Well, fooles may talke
Of Metridate, Cordials, and Elixars.
But from my youth this was my onely Physick.
Here's a colour, what Ladies cheek,
Though ceruss'd over, comes neere it?
It sparkles too: hangs out Diamonds.
O my sweet heart, how I will hug thee,
Again, and again! They are poor drunkards,
And not worth thy favours,
That number thy moyst kisses in these Christals.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: But Mounsiuer,
Here are Suckets, and sweet dishes.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Tush, boys meat,
I am past it; here's strong food fit for men:
Nectar, old lad. Mistris of merry hearts,
Once more I am bold with you.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Take heed (man)
Too much will breed distemper.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Hast thou liv'd at Sea
The most part of thy life, where to be sober
While we have Wine aboord, is capitall treason;
And dost thou preach sobriety?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: prethee forbeare,
We may offend in it; we know not for whom
It was provided.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am sure for me: therefore footra,
When I am full, let 'em hang me, I care not.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: This has been his temper ever. Enter Albert, Aminta, Raymond, Lamure, Morrillat, Franvile, severally.
See, provoking dishes, candid Eringoes,
And Potatoes.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ile not touch 'em, I will drink;
But not a bit on a march, Ile be an Eunuch rather.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Who are these?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Marry, who you will;
I keep my text here.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Raymond!

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Albert!

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Away, Ile be drunke alone;
Keep off rogues, or Ile belch ye into ayre;
Not a drop here.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Deere brother, put not in your eyes such anger;
Those looks poyson'd with fury shot at him,
Reflect on me. O brother looke milder, or
The Christall of his temperance
Will turn 'em on your selfe.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir have sought ye long
To finde your pardon: you have ploughed the Ocean
To wreak your vengeance on me, for the rape
Of this faire virgin. Now our fortune guides us
To meet on such hard terms, that we need rather
A mutuall pitty of our present state,
Then to expostulate of breaches past,
Which cannot be made up. And though it be
Far from your power to force me to confesse,
That I have done ye wrong, or such submission
Failing to make my peace, to vent your anger;
You being your selfe slav'd, as I to others:
Yet for your sisters sake, her blessed sake,
In part of recompence of what she has suffered
For my rash folly; the contagion
Of my black actions catching hold upon
Her purer innocence: I crave your mercy,
And wish however severall motives kept us
From being friends while we had hope to live,
Let death which we expect, and cannot fly from,
End all contention.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Drink upon't, 'tis a good motion;
Ratifie it in Wine, and tis authenticall.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: When I consider
The ground of our long difference, and look on
Our not to be avoyded miseries,
It doth beget in me I know not how
A soft religious tendernesse; which tels me,
Though we have many faults to answer for
Upon our own account, our fathers crimes
Are in us punisht. O Albert, the course
They took to leave us rich was not honest,
Nor can that friendship last, which vertue joyns not.
When first they forc'd the industrious Portugals,
From their Plantations in the happy Islands.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: This is that I watch for.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: And did omit no tyranny, which men
Inured to spoyle and mischiefe could inflict,
On the griev'd sufferers; when by lawlesse rapine
They reapt the harvest, which their labours sowed;
And not content to force 'em from their dwelling,
But layd for 'em at Sea, to ravish from 'em
The last remainder of their wealth; then, then,
After a long pursuit, each doubting other,
As guilty of the Portugals escape,
They did begin to quarrell, like ill men;
(Forgive me piety, that I call em so)
No longer love, or correspondence holds,
Then it is cimented with prey or profit:
Then did they turn those Swords they oft had bloodied
With innocent gore, upon their wretched selves,
And payd the forfeit of their cruelty
Shown to Sebastian, and his Collonie,
By being fatall Enemies to each other.
Thence grew Amintas rape, and my desire
To be reveng'd. And now observe the issue:
As they for spoyle ever forgot compassion
To women, (who should be exempted
From the extremities of a lawfull war)
We now, young able men, are faln into
The hands of women; that, against the soft
Tendernesse familiar to their sex, Enter Crocale.
Will shew no mercy.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: None, unlesse you shew us
Our long lost husbands.
We are those Potugals you talk'd of.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Stay,
I met upon the Sea in a tall ship
Two Portugals, famisht almost to death.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Our ship by this Wine.
And those the rogues that stole her,
Left us to famish in the barraine Islands.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Some such tale they told me,
And something of a woman, which I find,
To be my sister.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Where are these men?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I left 'em,
Supposing they had deluded me with forg'd tales,
In the Island where they sayd
They had liv'd many years the wretched owners
Of a huge masse of treasure.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The same men: and that the fatall muck
We quarreld for.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: They were Portugals you say.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: So they profes'd.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: They may prove such men as may save your lives,
And so much I am taken with faire hope,
That I will hazard life to be resolv'd on't:
How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: My ship lies by the rivers mouth,
That can convey yee to these wretched men,
Which you desire to see.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Back to your prisons,
And pray for the successe: if they be those
Which I desire to finde, you are safe;
If not, prepare to die to morrow:
For the world cannot redeem ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How ever, we are armd
For either fortune, Exit.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: What must become of me now
That I am not dismis'd?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: O sir, I purpose
To have your company.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Take heed wicked woman,
I am apt to mischiefe now.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You cannot be so unkind,
To her that gives you liberty.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: No, I shall be too kind, that's the devil on't;
I have had store of good wine: and when I am drunk,
Joane is a Lady to me, and I shall
Lay about me like a Lord: I feele strange motions:
Avoid me temptation.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Come sir, I'le help yee in. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: What may that be
That mooves upon the Lake?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Still it drawes neerer,
And now I plainly can descerne it.
Tis the French ship.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: In it a woman,
Who seemes to invite us to her,

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Still she cals with signes of Love to hasten to her;
So lovely hope doth still appeare:
I feele nor age nor weaknesse.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Though it bring death,
To us tis comfort: and deserves a meeting.
Or els fortune tyrd with what we have suffer'd,
And in it overcome, as it may be,
Now sets a period to our misery. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What dreadfull sounds are these?

sp.speaker: Amin
sp.l: Infernall Musick,
Fit for a bloody Feast.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: It seemes prepar'd
To kill our courages, e're they divorse
Our soules and bodies.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: But they that fearelesse fall,
Deprive them of their triumph.

sp.speaker: Aminta
sp.l: See the furies,
In their full Trym of cruelty.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Tis the last
Duty that I can pay to my dead Lord,
Set out the Altar, I my selfe wilbe
The Priest, and boldly do those horrid Rites
You shake to think on: lead these Captaines neerer,
For they shall have the honour to fall first
To my Sebastians ashes: and now wretches,
As I am taught already that you are,
And lately by your free confession,
French pirats, and the sons of those I hate,
Even equall with the devil; here with horror,
What tis invites me to this cruell course,
And what you are to suffer; no Amazons we,
But women of Portugall, that must have from you
Sebastian and Nicusa; we are they
That groan'd beneath your fathers wrongs:
We are those wretched women,
Their injuries pursu'd, and overtook;
And from the sad remembrance of our losses
We are taught to be cruell; when we were forc'd
From that sweet ayre we breathed in, by their rapine,
And sought a place of being; as the Seas
And winds conspird with their ill purposses,
To load us with afflictions, in a storme
That fell upon us; the two ships that brought us,
To seek new fortunes in an unknown world
Were severed: the one bore all the able men,
Our treasure and our Jewels: in the other,
We women were imbarq'd: and fell upon,
After long tossing in the troubled maine,
This pleasant Island: But in few moneths,
The men that did conduct us hither died,
We long before had given our husbands lost:
Remembring what we had suffred by the French,
We took a solemn Oath never to admit
The curs'd society of men: necessity
Taught us those arts not usuall to our sex:
And the fertile Earth yeelding abundance to us,
We did resolve thus shapt like Amazons
To end our lives; but when you ariv'd here,
And brought as presents to us our own Jewels;
Those which were boorn in the other ship,
How can ye hope to scape our vengeance?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: It boots not then to swear our inocence?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Or that we never forc'd it from the owners?

sp.speaker: Ray
sp.l: Or that there are a remnant of that wrack,
And not far off?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: All you affirme, I know,
Is but to win time; therefore prepare your throats,
The world shall not redeem ye: and that your cries
May find no entrance to our eares,
To moove pitty in any: bid lowd Musick sound
Their fatall Knels; if ye have prayers use 'em quickly,
To any power will own yea; but ha! Enter Crocale, Sebastian, Nicusa, Tibalt.
Who are these? what spectacles of misfortun?
Why are their looks
So full of Joy and wonder?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Oh! lay by
These instruments of death, and welcome
To your armes what you durst never hope to imbrace:
This is Sebastian, this Nicusa Maddam:
Preserv'd by miracle: look up deer sir,
And know your own Rossellia: be not lost
In wonder and amazment; or if nature
Can by instinct instruct you what it is,
To be blessed with the name of Father,
Freely injoy it in this faire Virgin.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Though my miseries,
And many years of wants, I have indur'd,
May well deprave me of the memory
Of all joyes past; yet looking on this building,
This ruind building of a heavenly forme
In my Rossella; I must remember, I am Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O my joyes!

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: And here,
I see a perfect modell of thy selfe,
As thou wert when thy choyce first made thee mine:
These cheecks and fronts though wrinkled now with time
Which art cannot restore: had equall purenesse,
Of naturall white and red, and as much ravishing:
Which by fayre order and succession,
I see descend on her: and may thy vertues
Winde into her forme, and make her a perfect dower:
No part of thy sweet goodnesse wanting to her.
I will not now Rossellia aske thy fortunes,
Nor trouble thee with hearing mine;
Those shall hereafter serve to make glad howers
In their relation: All past wrongs forgot;
I am glad to see you Gentlemen; but most,
That it is in my power to save your Lives;
You sav'd ours when we were neer starv'd at Sea,
And I despaire not, for if she be mine?
Rossellia can deny Sebastian nothing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She do's give up her selfe,
Her power and joyes, and all, to you,
To be discharged of 'em as to burthensome;
Wellcome in any shape.

sp.speaker: Sabast.
sp.l: Sir in your looks,
I read your sute of my Clarinda: she is yours:
And Lady if it be in me to confirme
Your hopes in this brave Gentleman,
Presume I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O Happy houre!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O my deer Aminta;
Now all our feares are ended.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Here I fix: she's mettle,
Steele to the back: and will cut my leaden dagger,
If not us'd with discretion.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are still no changling.

sp.speaker: Sabast.
sp.l: Nay,
All look cheerfully, for none shalbe
Denyd their lawfull wishes; when a while
We have here refresht our selves; wee'l returne
To our severall homes; and well that voyage ends,
That makes of deady enemies faythfull friends.
